title: Teaching
text:
3804ENV Marine Ecosystem Modelling
This course will provide students with the knowledge and quantitative skills needed for the management and conservation of marine living resources. Students will learn about the modelling methods that inform ecosystem management. Students will utilise the R programming environment to simulate the processes that determine marine ecosystem population dynamics. Prerequisite: Student must have completed 160CP.

title: Research
text:
Publications, code and media
Click on projects below to find links to publications, code/data and media coverage.
Please e-mail me if you do not have access to my work and I will gladly send you a PDF copy.
I strongly believe in open, reproducible science. I strive to make all data and code from my projects publicly available, where possible. You can find all available materials hosted on github and linked below.

title: Conservation Action Team
text: Ecosystems are increasingly threatened by human activities that can interact at different scales. The future of these ecosystems relies on actions to guide their sustainable use and conservation. In the Conservation Action Team, our research synthesizes new and existing data to quantify the what and where of human impacts on biodiversity from local to global scales and the actions that can be taken to reduce these threats. Our work largely falls within four main themes: 1) impacts of food production, 2) spatial conservation planning, 3) land-sea interactions and 4) achieving conservation targets. This work can be used to quantify patterns between different locations, assess trade-offs between management actions, and inform conservation and sustainable development decisions.

title: Media
text: You can find a selection of media coverage from our projects below.

title: Dr Caitie Kuempel
text:
Dr Caitie Kuempel




I am currently a Lecturer in Ecological Modelling at Griffith Univeristy (Brisbane, Australia).


PhD in Conservation Science | Nov. 2014-Aug. 2018 University of Queensland, Brisbane, Australia
MSc Marine Biology | Aug. 2011 - Dec. 2012 Northeastern University, Boston, MA, USA
BSc Environmental Science | Aug. 2007-May 2011 BA French | Aug. 2007-May 2012
University of Iowa, Iowa City, IA, USA



I am an experienced spatial modeler of environmental impact across a range of human activities and scales. These models can be used to quantify patterns and potential impacts on humans and nature, assess trade-offs between management actions, and develop systematic conservation plans.
Please see my CV and Griffith Expert page for more information.

title: Dr Caitie Kuempel
text: Caitie Kuempel is a lecturer in Marine Ecological Modelling at Griffith University.

title: Dr Caitie Kuempel
text: Education

title: Dr Caitie Kuempel
text: Experience

title: Data and Code
text: I strongly believe in open, reproducible science. I strive to make all data and code from my projects publicly available, where possible. You can find all available materials hosted on github.

title: The environmental footprint of global food production
text: We quantified pressures resulting from food production (cover 99% of food produced) including greenhouse gas emissions, freshwater use, nutrient pollution, and spatial disturbance. We then created a cumulative index to identify hotspots and relative efficiencies in production between sectors and locations.

title: Global fishing between jurisdictions with unequal fisheries management
text:
Fisheries can cause environmental degradation. These impacts can be displaced when one country fishes in another country’s waters. This may be particularly problematic when the fished country has less ability to manage it’s fisheries or marine resources than the fishiing country. We quantified the extent of “unequal” fishing displacement between countries to assess the countries who participate the most in this practice and the countries that potential are the most impacted.



Schematic of unequal fishing, credit Blake Alexander Simmons

title: Rights and representation support justice across aquatic food systems
text:
Blue foods support diets and livelihoods for billiones of people, but are unequal in their benefits. We assess economic, political and social barriers impacting participation in blue food produciton across 195 countries and found trade-offs between wealth-generating and welfare-sutaining benefits can threaten food security.



credit Khanh Hmoong

title: Demystifying ecological connectivity for actional spatial conservation planning
text:
There is a disconnect between global high-level conservation goals and onthe-ground actions such as maintaining ecosystem services or planning for protected areas, particularly for connectivity goals. We show how connectivity can be included in conservation planning objectives and connected to high-level goals.



Schematic of connections between high-level goals and spatial planning processes, credit Ari Balbar
